Author: pg
Content:
Do you think the CMUCL team who went on to make non-sexp based Dylan are just people who suck at programming?

No, but close. They were designing a language for other people who did. The original intention with Dylan was to create a Lisp that was made more accessible for mainstream programmers.

Ditto Guy Steele on Java: "we were not out to win over the Lisp programmers;\nwe were after the C++ programmers. We managed to drag a lot of them\nabout halfway to Lisp."

Author: pedalpete
Content:
A great idea for a site. I'm not a football, basketball or baseball fan, but seeing as fans like to be up on any each play when they are away from the game, etc. I think there is great potential for your site.

One thing you might consider (and I can't believe you were able to get consistent names for all the teams) is to use the team logos in your lists where the user selects the teams, etc.

Clearly you've put a ton of work into the site. it looks great, it's a great idea.

Author: jkkramer
Content:
I would be more inclined to do this if the book is non-technical. When you commit to reading a technical book, you're committing yourself to more than just the time spent reading: you're committing yourself to the time spent applying and fully understanding what you read -- installing tools, tinkering with syntax, coding, and so on. I've got enough of that now.

With non-technical books (literature, history, quality-of-life), most of the time will be invested into actual reading, with a bit of pondering and maybe discussing. We can have a conversation right away, and there's still knowledge and insight to be gained.

Here are some non-technical books I'd like to read:

* How to Read a Book - http://amazon.com/dp/0671212095

* Influence: The Psychology of Persuasion - http://amazon.com/dp/006124189X

* Liar's Poker - http://amazon.com/dp/0140143459

* Growing a Business - http://amazon.com/dp/0671671642

Author: smoore4
Content:
I know this is pretty much a totally closed post, but just to play devil's advocate here, and because truly believe in the original idea here that pain is necessary for pleasure, I'm gonna argue this point. The biggest problem with pleasure in the absence of pain is that without any pain, there would only be the most intense of pleasures, for in the absolute absence of black, you have pure white, correct? Therefore in the absolute absence of pain, u have pure pleasure.

However, this leaves us with the problem that not only would there be no change in the intensity of pleasure to actually signify the difference between normal and orgasms (just for example), but absolute pleasure, being the one and only feeling, would become outrageously normal.

Which leads back to life without death. The majority of people (every single person I've ever met) have serious issues with the concept of death. Maybe they're not afraid of it, but we have created entire religions simply because not one of us can imagine being non-existant, and so we created the afterlife. However, the fact that we are is defined by the fact that there are many who aren't. The problem with this idea is not a single one of us can make a conclusion based on our behavior is there was no death, for it is impossible for us (or at least for me) to comprehend a world in which there actually is no end of life. The example given about these philosophers is true, I doubt the would be bored, however the hundreds/thousands/however many years they would have been alive is no where near infinity. Without even a concept of death, life is no longer life, it simply IS. End of story. Our goals may very well be attained, but the fact that they would even be considered goals with no pleasure at attaining them and no pain at leaving them be is a bit of a mystery to me.

Author: thomasmallen
Content:
I'll briefly recommend "The Black Jacobins" by CLR James: A classical quasi-Marxist study of Toussaint L'Ouverture and the Haitian Revolution (the only widely successful slave revolt). Toussaint hacked the slave trade, colonial oppression, and the pernicious influence of the French, Spanish, English, and self-interested bourgeoisie mulattoes.

I'm about half-way through it right now. Good book.

Author: nostrademons
Content: If you follow through to the comments on the original Valleywag article, you'll see that this article's confusing two different bonuses.  The Google holiday bonus has always been about $1000 cash, so it's a cut of "only" 60% or so.  Not great, but better than the pink slips many Yahoo employees are getting.  The Google performance bonuses don't come out until March or so, so nobody will know how much they've been cut until then.

Author: webwright
Content: I'd second that.  If you are going out on your own, be a contractor, not a freelancer...  i.e. find big companies who will pay you $80+/hr for 40h a week on an ongoing basis.  The overhead and "bench time" (time between jobs) is more expensive than you think.
